title: Power, Stereotypes, and Gender
subject: Health and Physical Education
description: This topic examines how gender stereotypes and power dynamics influence relationships. Students explore how gender expectations can affect roles, decision-making, and behaviour in relationships, and learn to recognise unhealthy power dynamics. They develop skills for challenging harmful stereotypes and promoting equity in relationships.

curriculumDescriptions.VC2HP8P04: Examine the roles of respect, empathy, power and coercion in developing respectful relationships

contentSections.content:
Everyone deserves to be treated fairly and with respect.

What being fair means:
- Treating everyone kindly
- Giving everyone a chance
- Not leaving people out
- Listening to everyone's ideas
- Sharing opportunities

Unfair treatment:
- Leaving someone out because of who they are
- Saying someone can't do something because of their gender
- Making fun of people for what they like
- Not listening to some people

Why fairness matters:
- It makes people feel valued
- It helps everyone feel included
- It creates better friendships
- It's the right thing to do

contentSections.sectionTitle: You Can Like What You Like
contentSections.content:
Everyone should be able to enjoy the activities they like.

There are no 'boy things' or 'girl things':
- Anyone can like sports
- Anyone can like art
- Anyone can play any game
- Anyone can enjoy any colour
- Anyone can have any job when they grow up

Examples of people doing what they enjoy:
- Boys who love dancing
- Girls who love football
- Boys who love cooking
- Girls who love video games
- Anyone who loves anything!

What to do if someone says you can't:
- Know that it's okay to like what you like
- Talk to a trusted adult
- Remember that people are all different
- Find friends who accept you

In friendships, everyone should be treated fairly.

Fair friendships:
- Everyone gets to talk
- Everyone gets to decide sometimes
- No one is always in charge
- Everyone's ideas matter
- You take turns choosing activities

Unfair friendships:
- One person always decides
- One person always gets their way
- Someone's ideas are always ignored
- Someone is left out
- Someone is made to do things they don't want

If a friendship feels unfair:
- Talk to your friend about how you feel
- It's okay to want things to be fair
- Talk to a trusted adult if you need help
- Remember you deserve fair treatment

We can all help make things fairer.

What you can do:
- Include everyone in games
- Listen to everyone's ideas
- Don't make fun of what people like
- Be kind to everyone
- Speak up if something isn't fair

If you see someone being unfair:
- You could say 'That's not fair'
- Include the person being left out
- Tell a trusted adult
- Be a good example

Remember:
- Everyone deserves respect
- It's okay to be different
- We're all valuable
- Fairness makes things better for everyone

contentSections.content:
A stereotype is a fixed idea about a group that often isn't true for everyone in that group.

Examples of stereotypes:
- 'Boys don't cry'
- 'Girls aren't good at sports'
- 'Boys should be tough'
- 'Girls should be quiet'

Why stereotypes are harmful:
- They limit what people think they can do
- They make some people feel bad about themselves
- They're often not true
- They put pressure on people to act certain ways

The truth:
- Everyone is different
- Anyone can have any interest or talent
- People shouldn't be judged by stereotypes
- We are all more than just our gender

Society often has expectations about how boys and girls should act. These aren't always fair.

Expectations that can be limiting:
- Boys: Be tough, don't show emotions, like sports
- Girls: Be gentle, be helpful, like fashion

The problem with these expectations:
- Not everyone fits these boxes
- It's stressful to pretend to be something you're not
- People miss out on activities they might enjoy
- It can affect mental health

What's actually true:
- Anyone can be tough AND kind
- Anyone can enjoy sports AND art
- Anyone can show emotions AND be strong
- Being yourself is what matters

Remember:
- You don't have to fit expectations
- Being different is okay
- The best you can be is yourself

In healthy relationships, everyone should be treated fairly and have equal say.

Signs of equality in relationships:
- Both people's opinions matter
- Decisions are made together
- Both people can express their feelings
- No one is always in charge
- Both people's interests are valued

Unequal relationships:
- One person always decides
- One person's feelings don't matter
- One person is always told what to do
- One person controls everything

Equality applies to all relationships:
- Friendships
- Family relationships
- Any relationship

You have the right to:
- Be heard
- Have your feelings respected
- Make decisions about your own life
- Be yourself

We can all help challenge stereotypes and create a fairer world.

How to challenge stereotypes:
- Notice when someone makes a stereotype
- Question it: 'Is that really true for everyone?'
- Include everyone in activities
- Support people who don't fit stereotypes
- Be yourself, even if it's different

What you can say:
- 'That's not true for everyone'
- 'Anyone can enjoy that'
- 'That's a stereotype'
- 'People are all different'

Being an ally:
- Stand up for people who are treated unfairly
- Include people who are left out
- Don't laugh at jokes that put people down
- Be a good example

Remember:
- Challenging stereotypes helps everyone
- It takes courage but it's worth it
- Small actions make a difference
- Everyone benefits when we're fair

contentSections.content:
Gender stereotypes are fixed ideas about what people of different genders should be like, do, or feel.

Common gender stereotypes:

About boys/men:
- Should be tough and not show emotions
- Should be interested in sports and physical activities
- Should be strong and dominant
- Shouldn't cry or show vulnerability
- Should make decisions and be in control

About girls/women:
- Should be gentle and nurturing
- Should be interested in appearance and relationships
- Should be quiet and agreeable
- Should put others' needs first
- Should not be aggressive or assertive

Why stereotypes are harmful:
- They limit individuals' choices and potential
- They create pressure to conform
- They contribute to mental health problems
- They reinforce inequality
- They don't reflect the full diversity of people

The reality:
- People of all genders can have any interests, traits, or skills
- Expressing emotions is healthy for everyone
- Strength comes in many forms
- Everyone deserves to be their authentic self

Gender stereotypes influence how people behave in relationships and what they expect from others.

Impact on roles:
- Expectations about who does what in relationships
- Ideas about who should make decisions
- Beliefs about who should express emotions
- Assumptions about who leads and who follows

Impact on decision-making:
- Some people expected to take charge
- Some people's opinions valued less
- One person may dominate
- Unequal influence over choices

Impact on emotional expression:
- Some discouraged from showing feelings
- Some expected to manage others' emotions
- Limited emotional connection
- Pressure to hide true feelings

Impact on conflict:
- Beliefs about who should back down
- Different expectations for assertiveness
- Power imbalances in resolving disagreements
- Some voices not heard

Healthy relationships:
- Both people's opinions valued equally
- Decision-making shared
- Both can express full range of emotions
- Both can be assertive and also vulnerable

Power dynamics significantly affect relationship health. Understanding these helps recognise healthy and unhealthy patterns.

Healthy power in relationships:
- Power is shared and balanced
- Both people influence decisions
- Neither controls the other
- Both feel free to be themselves
- Differences are resolved respectfully

Unhealthy power patterns:

Control:
- One person makes all decisions
- Monitoring where the other goes or who they see
- Telling the other what to wear or do
- Not allowing independent choices

Coercion:
- Using pressure to get what you want
- Manipulation through guilt or emotional tactics
- Threats (direct or indirect)
- Making the other person feel they have no choice

Intimidation:
- Using anger to control
- Creating fear
- Physical presence or threats
- Making the other person feel unsafe

Warning signs:
- Jealousy and possessiveness
- Isolating from friends and family
- Criticism and put-downs
- Controlling behaviour
- Making someone feel scared
- Blaming the other for everything

Remember: Everyone deserves to feel safe, respected, and free in relationships.

We can all work to challenge harmful stereotypes and create more equal relationships and communities.

Personal actions:
- Be yourself, even if it doesn't fit stereotypes
- Pursue interests that matter to you, regardless of gender expectations
- Express your full range of emotions
- Challenge your own stereotyped thinking

In relationships:
- Share decision-making equally
- Value each other's opinions
- Allow everyone to express emotions
- Challenge controlling behaviour
- Support your partner's/friend's full self

Being an ally:
- Speak up when you see stereotyping or unfairness
- Support people who don't fit stereotypes
- Don't participate in gender-based put-downs
- Invite diverse people into activities

What you can say:
- 'That's a stereotype - it's not true for everyone'
- 'Anyone can be interested in that'
- 'I don't think that's fair'
- 'What makes you think that?'

Healthy masculinity includes:
- Showing emotions and vulnerability
- Respecting others as equals
- Not using power to control
- Supporting gender equality

Healthy femininity includes:
- Being assertive about needs and boundaries
- Pursuing any interest or career
- Not accepting unfair treatment
- Taking up space confidently

Creating relationships based on equality and mutual respect benefits everyone.

Principles of equal relationships:
- Both people's needs and wants matter
- Decision-making is shared
- Communication is open and honest
- Conflict is resolved respectfully
- Both feel free to be themselves
- Neither controls the other

Practices that promote equality:
- Active listening to each other
- Checking in about important decisions
- Respecting each other's independence
- Sharing responsibilities fairly
- Supporting each other's goals
- Celebrating differences

Addressing power imbalances:
- Recognise when imbalances exist
- Talk about fairness openly
- Actively work toward balance
- Seek help if needed

Red flags to address:
- One person always decides
- One person's needs always come first
- One person is isolated from others
- One person feels controlled or afraid
- One person dismisses the other's feelings

Getting help:
- Talk to a trusted adult
- School counsellors can help
- Kids Helpline: 1800 55 1800
- Relationships should feel safe

Girls gain freedom to be assertive, pursue any career, and not accept unfair treatment. Relationships become more equal and respectful. People can be authentic rather than conforming to expectations. Mental health improves when people aren't pressured into boxes. Communities become more diverse and inclusive. Everyone benefits from living in a place where people are valued for who they are, not judged by stereotypes about their gender.

learningIntentions: Critically analyse how gender is socially constructed and its impact on relationships

vocabularyTerms.definition: The idea that concepts like gender are created through social and cultural processes

contentSections.content:
Understanding gender as socially constructed helps us see how norms can be changed.

Biological sex vs gender:
- Sex refers to biological characteristics
- Gender refers to social meanings attached to being a boy/man, girl/woman, or non-binary
- Gender includes expectations, roles, and behaviours
- These vary across cultures and time periods

Evidence for social construction:
- Gender expectations differ across cultures
- They've changed throughout history
- Individual people express gender differently
- Biological differences don't determine personality or interests

How gender norms are created and maintained:
- Socialisation from birth (pink/blue, dolls/trucks)
- Messages from media, family, peers, schools
- Rewards for conforming, punishment for not conforming
- Repetition makes norms seem 'natural'

Implications:
- If gender norms are socially created, they can be changed
- 'That's just how boys/girls are' is an incomplete explanation
- Individuals can choose to follow or challenge norms
- Societies can work toward more equal expectations

Complexity:
- Biology and society both influence behaviour
- Change can be slow as norms are deeply embedded
- Individuals face real consequences for challenging norms
- Understanding construction doesn't mean change is easy

Experiences of gender and power are shaped by multiple intersecting identities.

What is intersectionality:
- Developed by Kimberl Crenshaw
- Different identities (gender, race, class, sexuality, ability) interact
- Creates unique experiences at intersections
- Can't understand gender in isolation

Examples of intersecting identities:
- Gender and race: Stereotypes differ based on race
- Gender and class: Economic power affects relationship dynamics
- Gender and sexuality: LGBTQ+ people face compounded challenges
- Gender and disability: Assumptions about capability
- Gender and culture: Different cultural expectations

Why intersectionality matters:
- Single-axis thinking misses important experiences
- Some people face multiple forms of disadvantage
- Solutions must address intersecting issues
- Avoids treating groups as homogeneous

Applications to relationships:
- Power dynamics affected by multiple factors
- Stereotypes vary based on intersecting identities
- Some face unique challenges in relationships
- Must consider full identity, not just gender

Being an effective ally:
- Recognise your own positions of privilege
- Listen to those with different experiences
- Understand that experiences vary within groups
- Address multiple forms of inequality

Some aspects of traditional gender expectations are particularly harmful.

Toxic masculinity refers to:
- Expectations that men should be dominant and aggressive
- Suppression of emotions except anger
- Viewing vulnerability as weakness
- Associating masculinity with control over others
- Homophobia and policing of 'unmanly' behaviour

Effects on boys and men:
- Pressure to hide emotions and vulnerability
- Higher rates of suicide (less likely to seek help)
- Difficulty forming close, intimate friendships
- Violence as acceptable expression of emotion
- Fear of being seen as 'feminine'

Effects on relationships:
- Power imbalances expected and normalised
- Emotional distance and communication problems
- Controlling behaviour seen as 'caring'
- Accepting disrespect as 'normal'

Healthy masculinity involves:
- Emotional expression and vulnerability
- Respecting others as equals
- Not using power to control
- Supporting gender equality
- Valuing diverse ways of being a man

Note: Critiquing toxic masculinity is not about attacking men. It's about challenging harmful expectations that hurt everyone and offering more positive alternatives.

Gender stereotypes and power imbalances contribute to relationship violence, which can be prevented.

Connection to gender norms:
- Beliefs about entitlement and control
- Normalising male dominance
- Expecting women to accept poor treatment
- Silencing victims

Forms of relationship violence:
- Physical: Hitting, pushing, hurting
- Emotional: Put-downs, manipulation, threats
- Social: Isolating from friends and family
- Financial: Controlling money and resources
- Digital: Monitoring, harassment online

Warning signs:
- Extreme jealousy or possessiveness
- Controlling behaviour
- Isolation from support networks
- Blame-shifting
- Escalating anger
- Disrespecting boundaries

Supporting friends:
- Listen without judgment
- Believe them
- Don't pressure them to leave
- Provide information about support
- Stay connected

Prevention involves:
- Challenging gender stereotypes early
- Teaching healthy relationships
- Developing bystander skills
- Creating cultures of respect

Support services:
- Kids Helpline: 1800 55 1800
- 1800RESPECT: 1800 737 732
- School counsellors

Effective change requires action at individual, relationship, community, and societal levels.

Individual level:
- Examine your own beliefs and assumptions
- Challenge internalised stereotypes
- Model healthy gender expression
- Develop critical media literacy
- Practice healthy relationship skills

Relationship level:
- Create equal, respectful relationships
- Communicate openly about expectations
- Support partners'/friends' full expression

Community level:

- Support inclusive policies at school

Societal level:
- Advocate for policy change
- Support organisations working for equality
- Challenge harmful media representations

- Contribute to cultural change

Active bystander strategies:
- Distract: Change the subject or create a diversion
- Delegate: Get help from others or authorities
- Direct: Address the behaviour directly
- Delay: Check in with the person later

Remember:
- Change takes time and persistence
- Small actions add up
- Everyone can contribute
- Challenging norms benefits everyone

relational.stem: Explain how the social construction of gender and toxic masculinity are connected in creating relationship problems.
relational.modelResponse: Social construction and toxic masculinity are connected because toxic masculinity is a product of socially constructed gender norms. Society creates expectations that men should be dominant, aggressive, and emotionally suppressed. These socially constructed norms become toxic masculinity when they lead to control, violence, and inability to form healthy relationships. Understanding that these norms are socially created shows they're not inevitable - they can be challenged and changed. Relationship problems like control, poor communication, and emotional distance stem from socially constructed expectations, not from inherent male nature.

extendedAbstract.stem: How might applying intersectional analysis and multi-level strategies together create more effective approaches to gender equality?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Combining intersectionality and multi-level strategies creates more effective approaches. Intersectionality shows that people experience gender differently based on their other identities - race, class, sexuality, ability. Strategies that ignore this may help some but not others. Multi-level thinking recognises change is needed at individual, relationship, community, and societal levels. Together: at individual level, we examine our assumptions about different groups; at relationship level, we understand power dynamics differ based on intersecting identities; at community level, we create inclusion that accounts for diverse experiences; at societal level, we address how systems disadvantage people at different intersections. Without intersectionality, multi-level strategies may only help the most privileged. Without multi-level thinking, intersectional analysis stays theoretical. Combined, they create comprehensive, inclusive change.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises both frameworks into integrated approach

contentSections.content:
Different theoretical frameworks offer distinct insights into gender and power.

Liberal feminism:
- Focus on equal rights and opportunities
- Works within existing systems for reform
- Emphasises individual choice and achievement
- Critique: May not address structural issues

Radical feminism:
- Identifies patriarchy as fundamental system of oppression
- Focuses on male violence and control
- Emphasises collective action and structural change
- Critique: May essentialize gender categories

Intersectional feminism:
- Centres how gender intersects with race, class, sexuality, ability
- Attends to diverse experiences
- Challenges single-axis thinking
- Critique: Can become fragmented; difficulty building coalitions

Queer theory:
- Challenges fixed gender/sexuality categories
- Emphasises fluidity and performativity
- Deconstructs 'natural' categories
- Critique: May be overly abstract; challenges to identity politics

Post-structural approaches:
- Focus on discourse and power/knowledge
- Gender as constructed through language and practice
- Attention to how norms are maintained and can be subverted
- Critique: May undermine basis for political claims

Using multiple frameworks:
- Each offers partial insight
- Different situations may call for different analyses
- Integrating perspectives provides richer understanding
- Critical awareness of each framework's limitations

Judith Butler's theory of gender performativity offers influential understanding of how gender works and can be changed.

Core concepts:
- Gender is not something we are but something we do
- Repeated performances create the appearance of stable identity
- No 'true' gender behind the performance
- Gender is constructed through citation of norms

How gender is performed:
- Dress, appearance, comportment
- Speech patterns and interaction styles
- Relationship to space and others
- Expression of emotion
- Everyday practices

The power of repetition:
- Norms gain power through constant repetition
- What's repeated seems 'natural' and inevitable
- Institutions enforce norms (school, media, family)
- Deviation is policed and punished

Possibilities for subversion:
- If gender is performed, it can be performed differently
- 'Failure' to perform norms reveals their constructed nature
- Alternative performances can challenge expectations
- Collective alternative performances shift norms

Limitations and critiques:
- How much agency do individuals have against structural constraints?
- Does emphasising performance ignore material conditions?
- Some worry it undermines women's claims based on shared experience
- Tension between theory and lived experience

Applications:
- Understanding how norms are maintained
- Identifying opportunities for change
- Valuing diverse gender expressions
- Recognising structural constraints on individual performance

Raewyn Connell's concept of hegemonic masculinity illuminates patterns of masculine power.

Hegemonic masculinity:
- The culturally dominant form of masculinity
- Not the most common, but the most influential norm
- Other masculinities measured against it
- Maintains gender hierarchy and male dominance

Characteristics of hegemonic masculinity:
- Heterosexuality and homophobia
- Dominance over women
- Emotional control (except anger)
- Physical strength and capability
- Competitiveness and achievement
- Risk-taking

Relation to other masculinities:
- Complicit: Benefit from hegemonic norm without fully embodying it
- Subordinated: Masculinities ranked lower (e.g., gay men)
- Marginalized: Affected by race, class, and other factors

How hegemony is maintained:
- Cultural representations
- Institutional practices
- Peer policing
- Economic structures

Alternative masculinities:
- Caring masculinity emphasising nurturing
- Inclusive masculinity accepting diverse expressions
- Pro-feminist masculinity actively challenging patriarchy
- Multiple healthy ways to be masculine

Change possibilities:
- Hegemony shifts over time
- Alternative models gain influence
- Requires both cultural and structural change
- Men can be agents of change

Gender-based violence is connected to power structures and can be addressed through prevention.

Theoretical understanding:
- Violence as tool of power and control
- Connected to gender norms and expectations
- Perpetuation requires cultural support
- Both individual and structural dimensions

Ecological model of violence:
- Individual: Personal history, beliefs
- Relationship: Family, peer dynamics
- Community: Social norms, institutions
- Societal: Gender inequality, cultural norms

Prevention approaches:

Primary prevention:
- Addressing root causes before violence occurs
- Changing cultural norms
- Education about healthy relationships
- Building skills and understanding

Secondary prevention:
- Early intervention when risk factors present
- Bystander programs
- Support for those at risk

Tertiary prevention:
- Response to those who have experienced violence
- Support services
- Holding perpetrators accountable

Evidence for prevention:
- Comprehensive approaches most effective
- School-based programs show promise
- Whole-community approaches work better than individual
- Long-term, sustained efforts needed

Young people's role:
- Challenging norms in peer groups
- Active bystander intervention
- Supporting those affected
- Advocating for better education
- Creating cultures of respect

Effective advocacy for gender equality requires theoretical sophistication and strategic thinking.

Principles for effective advocacy:

1. Theoretical grounding:
- Understand different frameworks
- Analyse root causes, not just symptoms
- Avoid approaches that may cause harm

2. Intersectional approach:
- Centre those most affected
- Address multiple forms of inequality
- Avoid universalizing from privileged experience

3. Multi-level strategy:
- Individual awareness and change
- Relationship practices
- Community norm change
- Structural and policy change

4. Evidence-informed:
- Know what research suggests works
- Evaluate approaches critically
- Adapt based on context

5. Coalition-building:
- Work across differences
- Build alliances with other movements
- Strengthen collective power

Challenges and responses:

Backlash:
- Progress often triggers resistance
- Need strategies for responding
- Stay focused on goals while addressing concerns

Co-optation:
- Surface change without substance
- Critical awareness of tokenism
- Pushing for meaningful transformation

Sustaining effort:
- Change is slow and difficult
- Self-care and collective support
- Celebrating progress while maintaining momentum

Hope and possibility:
- Significant progress has been made
- Young people are driving change
- Better futures are possible
- Your contribution matters

relational.stem: Explain how hegemonic masculinity and gender performativity together help us understand both the maintenance and potential transformation of gender norms.
relational.modelResponse: Hegemonic masculinity and performativity are complementary frameworks. Hegemonic masculinity identifies the culturally dominant masculine ideal that maintains gender hierarchy - men are measured against this norm, policed toward it, and benefit from it in varying degrees. Performativity explains how this dominance is maintained: through repeated performances that create the appearance of natural, stable gender. But performativity also opens transformation possibilities - if gender is performed rather than essential, it can be performed differently. Hegemonic norms can be challenged through alternative performances that reveal their constructed nature. Together, these concepts explain both why gender norms are so persistent (hegemonically enforced and constantly performed) and how they can change (alternative performances can shift what's hegemonic).
relational.rubric: Explains how both concepts work together for understanding and change

extendedAbstract.stem: Synthesise insights from gender theory, prevention research, and advocacy strategy to propose a comprehensive approach for young people working toward gender equality.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: A comprehensive approach integrates theory, evidence, and strategy. From performativity theory, we understand that everyday practices create and could transform gender norms - this gives young people agency in their daily interactions. From hegemonic masculinity, we identify the specific patterns that maintain inequality and can be challenged. Intersectionality ensures our approach centres those most affected and addresses multiple forms of inequality. Prevention research shows that comprehensive, multi-level, sustained approaches work best - individual attitude change isn't sufficient without community and structural change. Strategic thinking helps navigate challenges: building coalitions across difference, responding to backlash, avoiding co-optation. Practically: young people can perform gender differently in their own lives; build peer cultures that value diversity; be active bystanders; push for institutional change; connect to broader movements. This combines theoretical sophistication (understanding how gender works) with evidence (what creates change) and strategy (how to make it happen) for effective advocacy.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises theory, evidence, and strategy into comprehensive approach
